citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A female Boxer (Whiskey, id# 900217000688080) was observed to have a yellow discharge over the left eye. Upon closer
observation, the cornea was blue, opaque and appeared to have a roughened area. She was squinting and avoiding
sunlight. The licensee stated that Whiskey had been playing rough with another dog and the dogs were placed in
separate enclosures. The other dog had a slight injury and was taken to the veterinarian for examination. This eye injury
was not seen thus not provided with diagnosis and treatment. Eye injuries are painful and can quickly worsen if not
treated properly. Squinting is a significant indicator of pain and the discharge indicates that the eye is irritated. This dog
must be examined by a veterinarian for proper diagnosis and treatment. The medical records must be available for APHIS
officials upon request.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Inside the big building along the wall across from the enclosures, there were 2 small holes where the wall and floor join.
There was insulation material and rodent feces by a hole, indicating that rodents are in this area. There was a distinct
smell of rodent urine and feces in this area. Failure to control pests can cause contamination of food, surfaces and
increase the risk of disease hazards towards the dogs. The licensee must establish and maintain at all times an effective
program for the control of insects, external parasites affecting dogs, and birds and mammals that are pests, to promote
the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A female Boxer (Whiskey, id# 900217000688080) was observed to have a yellow discharge over the left eye. Upon closer 
observation, the cornea was blue, opaque and appeared to have a roughened area. She was squinting and avoiding 
sunlight. The licensee stated that Whiskey had been playing rough with another dog and the dogs were placed in 
separate enclosures. The other dog had a slight injury and was taken to the veterinarian for examination. This eye injury 
was not seen thus not provided with diagnosis and treatment. Eye injuries are painful and can quickly worsen if not 
treated properly. Squinting is a significant indicator of pain and the discharge indicates that the eye is irritated. This dog 
must be examined by a veterinarian for proper diagnosis and treatment. The medical records must be available for APHIS 
officials upon request. 
3.11(d)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Inside the big building along the wall across from the enclosures, there were 2 small holes where the wall and floor join. 
There was insulation material and rodent feces by a hole, indicating that rodents are in this area. There was a distinct 
smell of rodent urine and feces in this area. Failure to control pests can cause contamination of food, surfaces and 
increase the risk of disease hazards towards the dogs. The licensee must establish and maintain at all times an effective 
program for the control of insects, external parasites affecting dogs, and birds and mammals that are pests, to promote 
the health and well-being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
